title: Crypto Weekly: Kenya thinks digital, 'Bitcoin Jesus' pays up
summary:
STORY: From Kenya moving digital to the so-called "Bitcoin Jesus"... This is Crypto Weekly. 

:: Kenya gets digital

Kenyan lawmakers have passed a bill to regulate digital assets like cryptocurrencies.

They want to boost investment in the sector by putting clear rules in place for the emerging industry.

A senior policymaker said the move puts the East African nation close to joining others, including South Africa...

Who are the only African nations with laws to govern the digital assets industry.

:: IMF says get ready

International Monetary Fund Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva is telling member countries to accept the rapid developments of digital currencies.

She said that digitalization in fiat money was "very good and very powerful".

But differentiated this from unbacked cryptocurrencies, such as Bitcoin, which the IMF has long advised central banks to avoid as a reserve asset.

:: G20 cautions

While the IMF might be saying get ready, the G20 risk watchdog is saying be careful. 

It says there are "significant gaps" in countries' attempts to regulate fast-growing crypto markets.

The watchdog says it could potentially harm financial stability.

:: Bitcoin tumbles

Bitcoin and ether tumbled as U.S.-China tension ramped up, wiping out a recent rally.

It came as the U.S. and China began charging additional port fees on ocean shipping firms that move everything from holiday toys to crude oil.

Bitcoin fell to around $110,000 just over a week after it hit a record high above $126,000.

:: Bitcoin Jesus

An early investor in bitcoin dubbed the "Bitcoin Jesus" has agreed to pay nearly $50 million to resolve U.S. charges that he evaded paying tens of millions of dollars in taxes.

Roger Ver entered into a deferred prosecution agreement resolving mail fraud and tax evasion charges.

title: G20 risk watchdog warns of 'significant gaps' in global crypto rules
summary: PARIS/LONDON (Reuters) -There are "significant gaps" in countries' attempts to regulate fast-growing crypto markets, which could potentially harm financial stability, the G20's risk watchdog warned on Thursday.  The Financial Stability Board (FSB), a body founded in the aftermath of the global financial crisis, made a series of recommendations on rules for crypto in 2023, to try to bring it in line with the mainstream financial sector.  In Thursday's review, it said while some progress had been made, international implementation and coordination of rules remained too "fragmented, inconsistent, and insufficient to address the global nature of crypto-asset markets".
